The first statement is a conditional statement: "If the cake was chocolate, then the muffins were blueberry." In logical terms, this can be represented as "If P, then Q," where P is "the cake was chocolate" and Q is "the muffins were blueberry."

The second statement is "The cake was not chocolate," which is the negation of P, or "not P."

In logic, from "If P, then Q" and "not P," we cannot directly infer "not Q." This is a common logical fallacy known as "denying the antecedent." The truth of Q is not dependent solely on P being true; Q could still be true even if P is false.
